content.webTitle: Ann Widdecombe show in Lancashire theatre to go ahead amid gay remarks row

fields.headline: Ann Widdecombe show in Lancashire theatre to go ahead amid gay remarks row
fields.bodyText: A theatre has said it is determined to go ahead with a one-woman show by the new Brexit MEP Ann Widdecombe, despite a threatened demonstration and the withdrawal of support from a local arts group in protest at her apparent endorsement of gay conversion therapy. Tuesday night’s Strictly Ann Widdecombe – An Intimate Evening With at the Lowther Pavilion in Lytham St Annes, Lancashire, will be the first performance of the show since the former Conservative minister prompted outrage by saying that science “might produce an answer” to being gay. Two other venues, the Landmark theatre in Ilfracombe and the Garrick theatre in Altrincham, cancelled Widdecombe’s bookings after she made the remarks. Protesters are planning to demonstrate outside the Lowther Pavilion on Tuesday night an hour before the performance is due to begin, and a local arts listings group is threatening to withdraw its support for the theatre if the show goes ahead. But those running the Lowther Pavilion have defended the show on the grounds of freedom of expression. “The right of free speech in the theatre was long fought and should be protected so that all opinions can be represented,” the theatre’s management said in a statement. The Brexit party’s leader, Nigel Farage, who hosted a business breakfast at the Lowther Pavilion in the run-up to the EU referendum, took a similar line. Last week he defended her remarks as a “matter of conscience”. Lowther’s chairman, Tim Lince, said: “In developing the theatre not every presentation or performance will appeal to everyone but our policies are proving successful in being able to present a broad spectrum of shows.” Lancashire Arts, which says it has supported many shows at the venue, said it would no longer promote the pavilion in its listings. It claimed the theatre’s managers had “failed to discern the difference between opinion and bigotry”. In a statement it added: “We acknowledge that the Lowther is exercising its freedom of choice by hosting, and indeed commercially profiting from, this event. • This article was amended on 13 June 2019. An earlier version implied, incorrectly, that Lancashire Arts was a body which provided funding. Rather it is a group which promotes arts in the area via listings. This has been corrected.
